awd_titl_txt: FAST-TRAC: Identifying and Overcoming Barriers to Advanced Degree Attainment for Low Income Engineering Students
awd_abstract_narration:
The FAST-TRAC program at Tufts University School of Engineering will recruit, prepare, and support academically talented low-income undergraduate students to complete an MS in Engineering through Tufts' existing 5-year BS/MS program.  FAST-TRAC's core features will be early outreach, support of the student-research mentor relationship, skill-building workshops, and undergraduate research experiences.  Industry partnerships will connect students to current state of the art challenges in their fields. FAST-TRAC will establish a comprehensive and transferrable support framework to prepare low-income undergraduate STEM students for the increased rigor, culture, and expectations of a graduate program.

The FAST-TRAC research component will make significant contributions to the knowledge base about what inhibits and facilitates the matriculation of underrepresented and economically disadvantaged students into STEM graduate programs.  This program will characterize the needs, perceptions, and research competencies of low-income students pursuing graduate Engineering degrees, and will measure the effectiveness of each program component in helping students achieve the MS degree. The project will measure the contextual supports and barriers to pursuing graduate education or securing a position in industry using the social-cognitive theory of career choice and development. This measure has been extensively used in the study of career choice and successfully applied to examine the roots of gender and ethnic disparities in STEM disciplines.

por.por_cntn:
The "Fast-Trac" Program created sustainable pathways to encourage and support underrepresented and low-income students to pursue and succeed in graduate programs. There were several major initiatives that were developed to support these goals including confidence and competency  building via a suite of professional development workshops that spanned several areas including; communication, personal development, scholarly expertise, career preparation and leadership/collaboration.   Students also received a notation on their transcript for their participation. Students learned to engage in activities  beyond the institution such as in professional organizations meetings, including IEEE, SWE, NESBE, IEEE-HKN, ASME, and NAI.  A key goal was to help students become more resourceful in seeking out and securing growth opportunities. The program offered students their first experience to  travel to a professional meeting to present their work which subsequently  connected students to job and internship opporutunities  and offers to continue their graduate work in Phd programs at other institutions. Several students were elected to student leadership positions in these organizations. The students were provided training on intellectual property/patents so that they got exposure to entrepreneurship opportunities. Several Fast-trac Scholars participated in Master's capstone projects, where sutdents chose a university owned IP to commercialize or to create their own working with Engineering Management Teams from the Tufts Gordon Institute. A series of webinars called "Grad Lab" that was developed to help students succeed in all aspects of graduate school and was so successful, it  has now been disseminated to IEEE-HKN and other IEEE societies as a resource for students. The cohorts help craft themes of their interest to help direct the yearly distinguished lecturer series, where experts would present to the cohorts. One of the most popular themes centered around space technologies and finding  diversity role modelds in STEM.  To achieve this, several prominent female leaders in space technologies met with the cohort in a small group setting, while  each also presented to the general student population in a separate  larger audience event. This provided the  Fast-Trac Scholars cohort "VIP" access to the speakers. Having listening sessions and implementing changes to the program based on student input had a positive effect on the program because it showed that students' voices were valued and that they played an active role in improving the program for those that followed. Several survey instruments were created to measure the students' perspective coming into the program as well as well as their experiences and opportunities they gained being in the program. Every student  in the program participated in summer research experiences or a paid internship in a field related to their career aspriations. The program resulted in a 100% graduation rate from the MS program and 25% of the students went onto PHD programs. Some of the major barriers the program identified, was expectations that graduate financial aid needed to be at the same level as the amounts students received for their undergraduate programs. All Students participantsl worked part-time jobs and many were responsible for helping to support themselves and their families. Several students were single parents themselves. This challenge often times set them apart from the majority of their "traditional student" peers who did not need to work. An important component was the education of faculty members and staff  in DEIJ training to understand the bias' that could creep in when working with Fast-Trac Scholars who do not meet university requirements for special accomodations.  For instance, group projects would often meet at inconvienient times that were not conducive to caring for young children or realistic for students working part-time jobs. Faculty training  was needed to frame conversations with students in empowering ways and always emphasizing resources to support the students ability to continue in their studies. Parents of the students were identified as a major influence on the participants in both positive and negative ways. Communicating the impact of obrtaining a graduate degree opposed to securing a well-paid STEM position with only the BS degree created additional pressure on students. In response, parents where invited to celebrate their students' accomplishments throughout the program and ensure there were translations and translators available to accomodaate different languages. 

Fast-Trac has tranformed all Engineering MS degrees at Tufts University  and is a pillar for other univerisities to follow. Including professional development courses as credit-bearing courses that contribute to graduation requirements for the MS degree required a major mindset shift that has proven impactful for attracting and retaining students. While COVID presented challenges for all institutions, the creation of several on-line educational products, like the "grad lab" series to support students to be prepared to thrive in graduate programs, as well as "negotiation", and  "story telling: Finding your personal Voice" courses have help transform engineering education to develop well-rounded graduate students who are both technical saavy and prepared to be immediate technical leaders, whether as an entrepreneur or technical contributer.


Last Modified: 05/10/2024
Modified by: Karen A Panetta

Image
  • The Fast Trac Program was the foundation to level set students from underrepresented and low-income populations to pursue graduate education.
    Dr. Karen Panetta
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Karen A Panetta
    Fast Trac Ecosystem for Graduate Education
